title: Making a website
text:
I am currently creating a website, to encourage and help others to make their own website too.

Things to Consider

Purpose and goals
Target audience and user experience
Content and information



Outcomes
I hope to establish a digital presence that includes:

An overview of current and previous work.
A summary of papers I’ve read and events attended.
A list of how-to guides and general thoughts.



  
  
  
    
     Twitter
  
  
    
     LinkedIn

title: Portfolio
text:
Welcome to my Portfolio
Thank you for visiting my portfolio website. Here you will find a collection of my work, publications, personal projects, plans and designs, and achievements.

Publications
On this page, you will find a list of any publications I have written, such as articles or research papers.


Work
This page showcases my professional work experience, including projects and job responsibilities.


Personal Projects
This page displays any personal projects I have undertaken, such as hobby projects or side hustles.


Plans and Designs
Here you will find a collection of any plans or designs I have created, such as architectural plans or product designs.


Achievements
This page highlights any notable accomplishments or awards I have received throughout my career.
I hope you enjoy browsing through my portfolio. Feel free to contact me if you have any questions or want to connect.

Work




Personal Projects

title: Making a Quarto website
text:
What is Quarto?
Quarto is the most recent website creation tool, but has risen to become one of the most popular, in large part due to the reputation of the team making it. It is a website template tool, so you write in markdown (with a YAML header) and then you make Quarto render your markdown files into the website’s HTML.
All Quarto does is turn your Markdown files into HTML files, the format of which can be tweaked by the optional associated YAML header, telling Quarto how to decorate the webpages.
The YAML header controls the layout of the page. On each page in the template there will be a </> button, to reveal what the underlying Markdown+YAML source file is pre-Quarto conversion into HTML, if you so wished to know!
While there is a bit of a learning curve, using template website builders like Quarto is easier than making your own website and looks more professional and is super fast once you get used to it. Having looked around Quarto seems to do a decent job blending these facets to give you the best experience in terms of simplicity, speed, flexibility and quality.


What is this starter website?
The point of this website is as a more “feature rich” template.
The main Quarto website is also feature rich, and a good source of insipration, but I thought it would be easier to have this website as a starting point, so you can copy this website to your own repo as explained below, as explained below, to get a more feature rich website out of the blocks.
You can publish this website using GitHub pages, or on other platforms, see here.


Why should I have a website?

Documenting what you have read, learnt and thought online is useful for yourself and others.
Having a website where you can showcase yourself and your portfolio makes you stand out to employers (as does being active on GitHub, which writing on this website will make you appear).
As alluded to before, there is a small initial learning curve, before the process becomes fast. But the skills required are mainstream and highly useful (e.g. GitHub, Markdown, HTML).



Quick way to get your own website up and running in 3 minutes two steps!
Assuming you have a GitHub account that is:

Fork this repo (in the top right) of this page to make your own website repository.
Go into the settings of your new website repo, and edit the settings for “Pages” (on the middle left somewhere):
Under ‘build and deployment’, select branch=main and folder=/docs. Then your website should go live!




github pages settings






But how to edit the files…
This process has a couple of steps, but you need to edit it locally on your computer and render the markdown with Quarto, then push the files back up to GitHub.
You will need to have Quarto and Git installed on your computer and linked to your GitHub.
In short:

then download your github repo containing your website to your local computer.

Then you can edit the markdown files in a markdown (.md / .qmd) or notebook (.ipynb) editor of your choice.

Convert the markdown files into the HTML files, using Quarto.
Run “quarto render the_file_path_of_your_website_directory” in a terminal (or use the shortcut in VS Code / Jupyter Notebook if you have the relevant Quarto extension).
Push this local repository back up to the GitHub repository where your GitHub pages website is stored, using Git.



Advanced
You can also add javascript into your Quarto webpage, linked through the YAML header, to customise the webpage further. See here.


Useful links
Setting up Git and GitHub Quarto Guide

title: YAML options
text:
Here I summarise the Quarto docs, saying which bits were useful to me… Authoring - Markdown basics ::: content ::: ->

content

Asking CHATGPT about this notation… ME: do you know what ::: is? Maybe related to markdown. CHATGPT: The “:::” is often used in markdown as a way to create a horizontal rule, which is a line that separates content on a webpage or document. It is used to visually break up sections of content and make them easier to read. It is supported by many markdown parsers and can be used in many different platforms like Github, Jupyter notebook, etc. ME: is it related to breaks between cells in notebooks? CHATGPT: No, the “:::” is not typically used to indicate breaks between cells in notebooks. Notebooks, such as Jupyter, use specific syntax to separate code cells, such as using “—” or “***” in markdown cells or using “#%%” in code cells. It’s not a standard syntax, but some people use it as a way to separate cells in jupyter notebook but it is not officially supported and different from the standard way which is using the command “—” or “***” in markdown cell or using “#%%” in code cells. https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/markdown-basics.html Authoring - Article Layout .column-body-outset .column-page-inset .column-page .column-screen-inset .column-screen also can put direction on the end -right or -left. Using the margin: can put footnotes, citations and asides in the margin too. can also put like figures and stuff in the margin. https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/article-layout.html Navigation Overview Top Navigation Side Navigation Hybrid Navigation Page Navigation Page Footer Hiding Navigation Reader Mode Site Search GitHub Links Redirects 404 Pages https://quarto.org/docs/websites/website-navigation.html Document Listings (make a structured list of things on a web page) Listing Contents (a whole folder, or specific files/folders) Listing Options Default Grids Tables User Tools Sorting dropdown Filtering dropdown Pagination (showing a finite number pf posts at once and splitting the list of posts over multiple pages) Listing Location (e.g. listing sandwiched between texts) Multiple Listings Listing Fields (e.g. [image, date, title, author, reading-time]) Customizing Fields Listing Sorting and Tags https://quarto.org/docs/websites/website-listings.html Extra on Listings Listing templates (In addition to the 3 built in types of listings can make custom listings) Dealing with listing metadata and customising it Points to the gallery to show examples of quarto websites https://quarto.org/docs/websites/website-listings-custom.html Page Layout page-layout (article, full, custom) in custom, can make grid with different column widths https://quarto.org/docs/output-formats/page-layout.html#custom Themes https://quarto.org/docs/output-formats/html-themes.html Extra Website Things Headers & Footers Social Metadata Google Analytics Cookie Consent Site Resources Dark Mode https://quarto.org/docs/websites/website-tools.html How .yml files and headers combine https://quarto.org/docs/projects/quarto-projects.html Processing foreign notebooks into a good format https://quarto.org/docs/extensions/nbfilter.html Interactivity (e.g. sliders on plots) https://quarto.org/docs/interactive/

title: About
text:
Essentially, I just made this website to include as many of the template features in the YAML as possible.
So you are free to keep or delete whatever features and make your own website from here.
The main Quarto webpage is also a feature rich website, and so the GitHub repo is good to look at.

title: Home
text:
This is a Quarto website.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.
